title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates that unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income when discharged. This includes applicable child support payments required under a support instrument for the taxpayer's child. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires eligible taxpayers to send a notice to individuals who failed to make payments, informing them of the amount of applicable child support payments to be included in their gross income for the preceding taxable year. If the taxpayer does not have the individual's address, the Secretary will provide the notice. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates eligible taxpayers to notify individuals who missed payments about the applicable child support payments to be included in their gross income for the previous taxable year. If the taxpayer lacks the address, the Secretary will send the notice. If the address is unknown, no income will be included for any taxable year before the year preceding the year of notice. Subsequent payments can be deducted in the year they are made. Definitions for "applicable child support payments" and "eligible taxpayer" are as per section 166(f). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999, and define "applicable child support payments" and "eligible taxpayer" as per section 166(f). SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers, with a limit of $10,000 per child. Eligible taxpayers are individuals with a certain adjusted gross income. The amended Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments up to $10,000 per child. Eligible taxpayers must have an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000, unpaid child support payments of $500 or more, and meet identification requirements. Applicable child support payments include periodic fixed payments or payments for medical, educational, or insurance expenses. The amended Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments up to $10,000 per child. Qualifying child refers to a child for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151. Payments must be delinquent for at least an entire year to qualify for the deduction. Payments must be delinquent for at least an entire year to qualify for the deduction. Coordination with TANF is required, and identification requirements must be met. The deduction under this subsection requires the eligible taxpayer to include specific identification information on the return, such as the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of the child and the individual responsible for child support payments. Cost-of-living adjustments apply for taxable years after 2000. Cost-of-living adjustments apply for taxable years after 2000, increasing specified dollar amounts based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. Subsequent payments that were previously deducted must be included in the taxpayer's gross income for the year paid, except if the right to receive the payment has been assigned to a State. The paragraph discusses the conditions under which child support payments can be deducted and the types of support instruments that qualify. It also introduces a new deduction for unpaid child support payments. The amendment allows for the deduction of unpaid child support payments under section 166(f) of the tax code, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will only be used to pay off US public debt, as specified in appropriation Acts, and cannot be used for any other purpose, regardless of other laws not mentioning this section.
